Award.AwardTitle: Transitioning into Adulthood during the Great Recession

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Robert Crosnoe
Shannon E. Cavanagh
Leticia Marteleto
University of Texas at Austin

The Great Recession has generated widespread concerns that contemporary cohorts of youth making their way into adulthood are in danger of becoming a lost generation. This project explores these concerns by examining how the Great Recession has affected many of the statuses that signal the transition from adolescence into adulthood, including various aspects of socioeconomic attainment and family formation. Potential effects involve both the length of time that young people in their late teens and early twenties take to acquire these statuses and the various ways that they combine them. Special attention will be paid to the potential for these effects to vary across diverse racial/ethnic and socioeconomic groups in the U.S., across geographic locales that were more or less hard hit by the economic downturn, and across the U.S.-Canada border, given how the recession started here and then filtered northward. The theoretical value of this research lies in its ability to inject sociological and developmental thinking into considerations of macro-level economic processes, including the ways in which short-term historical events shape long-term trajectories, the potential for young adulthood to be a critical period in the life course, and the interplay of socioeconomic and family experiences. More practically, by unpacking the scarring effects of a major economic recession, this project will serve the future interests of the youth actually undergoing that recession as they age into the next generation of workers, parents, and citizens and identify future youth who may be especially vulnerable in any of the inevitable recessions yet to come. Overall, the goals of the study are to develop a multi-dimensional understanding of the specific case of young adults in the Great Recession that advances interdisciplinary thinking among scientists, inform the public about an issue of great interest, provide valuable training opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students, and better serve the interests of American youth.

Drawing on life course concepts such as standardization and individualization as well as related areas of research, this project will test two set of competing hypotheses. First, did the Great Recession speed up or slow down the acquisition of major young adult statuses (e.g. full time employment, general higher education enrollment/STEM studies, marriage/partnership, and parenthood)? Second, did the Great Recession lead to more disordering or coupling of these statuses during young adulthood? To test these hypotheses, this project will apply multiple statistical tools (e.g., sibling fixed effects, latent class analysis, joint entropy calculations) to survey and geocode data from multiple 18-25 year old cohorts in the National Longitudinal Study of Youth 1979-Young Adult Survey. The prevalence of young adult school and work statuses (in general, within STEM) will be compared across multiple points before and after the start of the Great Recession (specifically, 2004, 2006, 2008, and 2010) and in relation to variable state and local economic conditions (e.g., unemployment rates). Moreover, the ways in which these statuses go along with (or not) with partnership and parenting before, during, and after the Great Recession will be assessed, with special attention to socioeconomic, racial/ethnic, and gender disparities in these transitional patterns over time. Integrated data analysis and group modeling will then adapt the U.S. models to the Canadian National Longitudinal Survey of Children and Youth for a selected cross-national comparison designed to shed light on the U.S. case.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Great Recession—the severe global economic crisis that lasted roughly from 2007 through 2009 with a residue lingering even today—generated widespread concerns among Americans that young people making their way into adulthood during this time were in danger of becoming a lost generation. With data from the National Longitudinal Study of Youth 1979-Young Adult Cohort and several other data sources, this project explored this possibility, ultimately finding some ways that young people appeared to struggle but also discounting the notion that their adult lives were effectively over before they began.

Specifically, we compared cohorts of U.S. youth in the 18-24 age range before, during, and after the Great Recession on their school, work, partnership (i.e., marriage or cohabitation), parenthood, and health outcomes to determine who was most affected and how by this historic economic downturn. We also tracked individual youth who spent some time in the 18-24 age range during the Great Recession to determine whether this crisis got them off track just as they were becoming adults. Overall, the results showed that young adults today are generally delaying the acquisition of key adult roles compared to young adults of the past and that the Great Recession magnified this trend. Nevertheless, the Great Recession did not have particularly powerful or consistent effects overall. Instead, different youth appeared to be affected in different ways, both positively and negatively and both contributing to inequality and reducing it.

First, the long-term trend of rising college enrollment continued through the Great Recession, with an uptick among teenagers and among young women in the most economically stable communities (defined by lower-than average unemployment and foreclosure rates), more enrollment in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields among male young adults, and a decrease in disparities in male STEM enrollment between the hardest-hit communities and more economically stable communities in the aftermath of the Great Recession. These trends contrast what happened in some Latin American countries, where college enrollment dropped during the Great Recession.

Second, the long-term trend among U.S. young adults towards the decoupling of marriage and fertility (i.e., having children outside of marriage) increased after the Great Recession. Moreover, transitioning into adulthood during the Great Recession was associated with a reduction in marriage, as young adults turned to cohabitation or stayed single instead, unless they lived in economically unstable communities. Young adults were actually more likely to marry during the 18-24 range, which is below the national average age at first marriage, if they lived in such communities.

Third, the clearest case of young adults being negatively affected by the Great Recession concerned health. Young people who transitioned from adolescence into adulthood during the Great Recession reported poorer health than those who did so before the Great Recession, especially when they came from more disadvantaged circumstances, and young adults also smoked more during the Great Recession, especially when they lived in communities that were hit hard by the economic crisis.

Overall, this project has many take-aways: 1) young adults faced risks during the Great Recession, but many showed resilience; 2) young people in their late teens when the Great Recession began tended to be more affected in both positive and negative ways than those in their early twenties; 3) family formation and health were more affected by the Great Recession than education and work, including negatively affected; 4) these effects most often appeared during the recovery period rather than the Great Recession itself, suggesting that young adults and their families course-corrected in its aftermath; and 5) young adults could be affected by the Great Recession even when their families or communities were not directly disadvantaged by this economic crisis, but economic volatility in their families and communities did pose risks to young adults during the Great Recession.

These findings are described in a series of manuscripts that are currently under consideration in peer-reviewed journals.
